Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example:
un kɵn
[10 day]
‘ten days’

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Detailed comment:
coordination: hEm, da/dE, Da/DE, la/lE, ta/tE
comitative: m@nEn ‘with, together with’

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Detailed comment: Yuldashev (1981:155): two demonstratives for proximal objects, two demonstratives for distal objects or known before the communicative situation; Poppe (1964:43): only a two-way distinction, other demonstratives are referential
Example:
bїl ‘this’
šul ‘that’

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Detailed comment: suffix -lar/-l@r, -tar/-t@r, -dar/-d@r, -Dar/-D@r, depending on the stem-final sound

Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?

Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
ɣärifulla-lar
[Garifulla-PL]
‘Garifulla and his family’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?

Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Example:
arḳa-m [back-1SG] ‘my back’
baš-їŋ [head-2SG] ‘your head’
öj-öböδ [house-1PL] ‘our house’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example: human huneke [book your] ‘your book’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Comment: Nominals are either unmarked used predicatively or take a predicative suffix indicating person and number as well as a plural number agreement suffix. Poppe (1964:87): there is no number agreement. Number of the S/A argument is not marked on the verb -> number marked on the adjective cannot be considered “acting like verbs”
Example:
kän jїlї
[day warm]
‘The day is warm.’
šulaj δa höjkömlö-lär
[so also cute-PL]
‘But they are so cute.’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Example:
elbäδäk ḳar [fluffy snow] ‘fluffy snow’
homɣol yeget [slim guy] ‘slim guy’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
šabata-nї babaj baδar-Ra iltep hata. 
[shoes-ACC old.man market-DAT bring.3SG sell.3SG]

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Detailed comment:
past definite tense -dї
past indefinite tense -ɣan
Example:
al-dї-m
[take-PST.INDEF-1SG]
‘I took (it).’
al-ɣan-mїn
[take-PST.DEF-1SG]

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Comment: indefinite past tense marker can have perfective meaning: the speaker uses it to indicate that he can evaluate a past event only according to its result, its impact on the present, without having seen the event

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?

Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?

Comment: In reported speech S is marked as P.

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?

Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?

Comment: it is Not mentioned. in the list of functions of the dative case, which normally marks the recipient, that it can also mark the patient
Detailed comment:
it is Not mentioned. in the list of functions of the dative case, which normally marks the recipient, that it can also mark the patient.
There is variation at least in marking of P by dative vs. accusative case.

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?

Comment: There is a dedicated predicative suffix on nominals used predicatively. In past tense, there is a copula.
Example:
1SG -mїn/-mon/-men/-mön
2SG -hїŋ/-hoŋ/-heŋ/-höŋ
3SG -dїr/-dor/-der/-dör/-tїr etc. /-δїr etc. /-lїr etc.

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?

Comment: It is not clear whether the words can inflect.

al- ‘be able to’
bul- ‘be able to’
kil- ‘want to’

Detailed comment:
predicate is in 1PL form if at least one acting subject is 1SG: ‘I with him went.we’
“The predicate is a plural form although the subject is a singular, when the subject is linked to the other actor by means of  the preposition menEn ‘with'. In other words, such expressions as 'he went with his friend' require a plural-predicate"
Example:
Sabir menEn MExmEt ɵф-gE kittelEr
[Sabir with Mahmut Ufa-DAT go.PST.PL]
‘Mahmut went together with Sabir to Ufa.'
